sentence.text: ﻿A 7-month-old female baby and her mother visited the surgical outpatient clinic of Kilimanjaro Christian Medical Center in Moshi, Tanzania.
This is a referral hospital in Northern Tanzania.
She reported that her child was born with an abnormal head size and shape with abnormal fingers and toes, but otherwise developing well.
It is the firstborn child to the parents, born at term by an uncomplicated vaginal delivery and with a birth weight of 4,000 g (above 90th percentile).
The mother had an uneventful pregnancy, but reported a miscarriage 2 years earlier at 10-weeks of gestation.
On examination, the child was 10.5 kg (97th percentile) with a length of 69 cm (47th percentile).
Weight for length was above 98th percentile (indicating obesity).
She was able to sit without support, crawled, responded to visual, and acoustic stimuli, recognized her parents and did not like to be held by others.
She followed objects, grabbed, and held them with her hands.

Examination of the head showed an asymmetric skull with cloverleaf shape, metopic ridge and temporal bulging, arched eyebrows, telecanthus, epicanthal folds, down slanting palpebral fissures, and anteverted nares (Figure 1).
Upon abdominal examination, there was a reducible umbilical hernia of 2 cm in diameter (Figure 1).
The external female genitalia were normal.
Musculoskeletal examination of the limbs showed broad thumbs with brachydactyly, syndactyly, and polydactyly.
The feet showed broad halluces and bilateral talipes equinovarus (Figure 1).A plain chest X-ray was essentially normal with clear lung fields and normal appearing cardiac shadow.
Cardiac and abdominal–pelvic ultrasonography studies showed no abnormalities.
Plain X-ray of hands and feet revealed postaxial polydactyly (Figure 1).
Head CT-scan showed hydrocephalus with dilated lateral and third ventricles with posterior fossa crowding and craniosynostosis.
Three-dimensional (3D) virtual-reconstruction images showed the cloverleaf shaped skull bone configuration (Figure 1).
